content:
e as applied to a man’s body such as “if you pinch
him he will squeak.” If we substitute “laws of behavior which regulate his
life” for “laws of conduct by which he regulates his life” in the argument
quoted the undistributed middle is no longer insuperable. For we believe
that it is not only true that being regulated by laws of behavior implies be-
ing some sort of machine (though not necessarily a discrete state machine),
but that conversely being such a machine implies being regulated by such
